definitions.definition: One's independent faculty of choice ; the ability to be able to exercise one's choice or intention .
examples: Of course, man's will is often regulated by his reason.

definitions.definition: The act of choosing to do something; a person’s conscious intent or volition .
examples: Most creatures have a will to live.

definitions.definition: One's intention or decision ; someone's orders or commands.
examples: Eventually I submitted to my parents' will .

definitions.definition: Firmity of purpose , fixity of intent
A formal declaration of one's intent concerning the disposal of one's property and holdings after death; the legal document stating such wishes.
That which is desired; one's wish.
Desire , longing . (Now generally merged with later senses.)
examples: He felt a great will to make a pilgrimage to the Holy Land.

main_definition: One's independent faculty of choice ; the ability to be able to exercise one's choice or intention . [from 9th c.]
secondary_definitions: The act of choosing to do something; a person’s conscious intent or volition . [from 10th c.]
One's intention or decision ; someone's orders or commands. [from 9th c.]
Firmity of purpose , fixity of intent
( law ) A formal declaration of one's intent concerning the disposal of one's property and holdings after death; the legal document stating such wishes. [from 14th c.]
( archaic ) That which is desired; one's wish. [from 10th c.]
( archaic ) Desire , longing . (Now generally merged with later senses.) [from 9th c.]
